Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site will support a diverse group of computing majors in a mentored research experience in computational robotics, including components emphasizing professional and academic skills development and community building. The primary population of target students will be sophomores and juniors from undergraduate-serving institutions in the southeast. The project will encourage these students toward graduate study and research-oriented industry positions, and provide essential preparation for these career paths. It will be an excellent opportunity for ten undergraduates to participate in research projects each year. The emphasis on applications of computing in robotics is supportive of the growing social need for such expertise. The selection process for these students will promote the inclusion of underrepresented groups through targeted publicity and outreach efforts.

Research conducted by the students will lead to more effective approaches to robot perception, control, and interaction. The research also includes projects rooted in areas such as software engineering, security, and automated reasoning that are often overlooked by the contemporary robotics community, but crucially important for the deployment of reliable, trustworthy robotic systems. The research projects will be organized around the observation that "Robots Change Everything." That is, every aspect of a computer system, from the design and engineering of its software, to its interactions with humans, to its core functions of perception and movement, is deeply impacted by the way robots must interact with the physical world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of South Carolina REU site in Applied Computational Robotics provided opportunities for 27 undergraduates to participate in ongoing research projects during its three years of operation as an REU site. An additional 5 students received support for research participation during the following year. The project created opportunities by recruiting participants represented a diverse range of backgrounds, including many participants from groups typically underrepresented in computing and robotics, and many participants from primarily undergraduate institutions. All participants worked with faculty and graduate student mentors. The site participants also participated in a structured series of seminars and workshops covering a wide variety of research topics and professional opportunities. The intellectual merit included research conducted by participants on more effective approaches to robot perception, control, and interaction. The research also includes projects rooted in areas such as software engineering and networking that are often overlooked by the contemporary robotics community, but crucially important for the deployment of reliable, trustworthy robotic systems. Broader impacts included opportunities for undergraduates to participate in research projects each year. The experience contributed to workforce development by equipping the participants to transition to graduate study or research-oriented professional industry careers in robotics and related areas of computing.
